body.name: Generation Ship: A Novel
body.description: In this riveting, stand-alone novel from Michael Mammay, author of Planetside, the beginning of a new human colony must face tyrannical leaders, revolution, crippling instability, and an unknown alien planet that could easily destroy them all.In 2108, Colony Ship Voyager departed Earth for the planet of Promissa with 18,000 of the world’s best and brightest on board. 250 years and 27 light years later, an arrival is imminent.But all is not well.The probes that they’ve sent ahead to gather the data needed to establish any kind of settlement aren’t responding, and the information they have received has presented more questions than answers. It’s a time when the entire crew should be coming together to solve the problem, but science officer Sheila Jackson can’t get people to listen.With the finish line in sight, a group of crewmembers want an end to the draconian rules that their forebearers put in place generations before. However, security force officer Mark Rector and his department have different plans. As alliances form and fall, Governor Jared Pantel sees only one way to bring Voyager’s citizens together and secure his own power: a full-scale colonization effort. Yet, he may have underestimated the passion of those working for the other side...Meanwhile, a harsh alien planet awaits that might have its own ideas about being colonized. A battle for control brews, and victory for one group could mean death for them all.

reviews.reviewerName: Chris Gerrib, Author, One of Our Spaceships is Missing
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A great stand-alone read!
reviews.reviewText: I’ve been a fan of Michael Mammay since his first book came out, so when I got an opportunity to read a pre-release copy of his latest novel Generation Ship I jumped at the chance. It’s a great read and I’m proud to recommend it to all fans of hard science fiction.The story is simple – the good ship Voyager is ending it’s 250+ years-long trip to the Zeta Tucanae system. (This is a real star, 28 light years from Earth.) There is an Earthlike planet called Promissa which the 18,000 humans on the ship plan to colonize. Our story starts 140 days or cycles prior to arrival and it’s not much of a spoiler to say problems have arisen. More like mysteries, as the advance probe sent to the planet has lost contact with Voyager.Mammay’s novels are full of intrigue, and this one is no exception. The five main characters in the book all have very different wants and needs, and those are in conflict with each other. Some just want to have a “normal” life, however that’s defined on a tightly-packed spaceship, while others have grander visions. How these people interact with each other while solving the larger mystery of Promissa drive this story.There are several things I really like about this book that I want to call out. First, Mammay does a great job of depicting change within stasis. The political system of the ship has evolved over the centuries, but because of the environment, much has stayed the same. Second, Mammay does a great job with character growth. All of the main characters start at one level and evolve, sometimes reluctantly, into another. There are no “chosen ones” or self-selected heroes in this book. Lastly, the mystery of Promissa is well set up. Frankly I would like to have learned more about the planet than I did.I think any fan of hard science fiction would love this novel. Order it now!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good realistic hard mix of sci-fi and realism
reviews.reviewText: This is a great book - you get a lot of characters to care about - an interesting scenario and problems and you get very much bound up in caring how it turns out.A nice mix of realism, science, social issues/politics amid long term human exploration planning. I definitely enjoyed it!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Ok, but a little light on the scifi aspects
reviews.reviewText: Lot of petty ship drama that seemed incongruous with the setting. The scifi aspects were secondary and could have used more development. Underwhelming and quick ending.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A truly great read!
reviews.reviewText: Generation Ship by Michael Mammay is a story about a long-haul colony ship to another star system. This is by far the best novel of this type I have ever read. I have read many novels of this type over the years and they all had a common storyline in that the story takes place many years into their journey with many more yet to go. In these stories the technology starts to break down or the crew mutinies or many times both. This novel is different in that the story takes place at the end of the journey with the ship approaching a new world to colonize. The ship's technology has worked remarkably well but as the day of arrival approaches the crew is at odds about how and when to start landing people on the planet. Life is discovered on the planet which further fragments the crew's opinions. This novel is told from several viewpoints and none of them are really bad guys or good guys. They are just people trying to do what they think is best for themselves and those around them. There is much political intrigue in this novel and a fair amount of action also. A truly great read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars An excellent book! Perhaps his best yet-
reviews.reviewText: I love Mammay's Planetside series, but this is different. While the Planetside series are roller-coaster rides of action and intrigue, Generation Ship has all of the intrigue, but with deliberate pacing that pulls you into the story.Mammay's use of multiple protagonists gives the reader the dynamic perspective of real life. Combined with a looming countdown calendar, these add subtle tensions to the developing storyline.Beyond science-fiction, this novel is also an excellent political commentary without any judgment. Who am I cheering for? Ultimately, everyone, the stakes are too high not too.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Generation Ship explores the politics onboard a colony ship, the Voyager, 250 years after it departed. With their destination closing in by the day tensions rise to the surface onboard the ship. Also, the planet? May not be uninhabited. I enjoyed the multiple points of view, and diverse cast of characters. The Governor could have been shot out of an airlock and I wouldn’t have been upset. If you enjoy politics then Generation Ship is for you. The ending was left open, I do wonder if he will write another closely related stand-alone.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This books covers all sorts of topics in thoughtful, nuanced manner. It explores how and why organized crime works, it details politics, psychology, exobiology, and even shows how mobs form, and why violence sometimes breaks out between citizens and law enforcement. It really moves from one topic to another, seamlessly, and explores all kinds of things. I am very interested in reading more works by this author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Too dependent on poetic license.
reviews.reviewText: I follow our own space programs rather closely. So I'm hard to please, take that into account when you read the following: This author relies on poetic license, ignoring current capabilities, and some stuff that's been around since the very beginning of the space program, to such a degree it pops me right out of suspended disbelief. Pretty common in sci-fi these days.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does for generation ship novels what Andy Weir’s “The Martian” did for stranded on Mars novels.
reviews.reviewText: I have followed Michael Mammay (and purchased his books) from the beginning of my writing journey.His openness about the industry, and that he writes books that are as good as his tips and advice, ensures I continue to purchase everything he writes.Generation Ship is his best work by far. With engaging characters, and a unique plot twist, I can’t say enough good things about it. At least not without spoilers.Highly recommended.
The novel is compelling and absolute fun to read. Shows what future space journeys will be like and political power struggles.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 18, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Awful too many characters story just wanders all over the place a waste of time and money
